examples.text: Tū mē amās, egō tē amō; meritō id fierī uterque exīstumat.
examples.ref: c. 200 BCE, Plautus, Mostellaria I.iii
examples.english: You love me, I love you; and each of us believes it to be well-deserved.

examples.text: Sī vīs amārī, amā.
examples.ref: c. 4 BCE – 65 CE, Seneca the Younger, Letters to Lucilius IX.6
examples.english: Love if you wish to be loved.

glosses: to be fond of, like, admire

examples.text: ...hīc magnōs potius triumphōs, hīc amēs dīcī pater atque prī̆nceps, neu sinās Mēdōs equitāre inultōs // tē duce, Caesar.
examples.ref: 17 BCE, Horace, Carmen Saeculare
examples.english: ...rather, may you delight in these great triumphs, to be called father and the first man (of state), and may you not allow the Medes to ride unpunished while you lead, Caesar.

glosses: to be pleased by or with (someone or something) for (a particular reason); to derive pleasure from...(for...), delight in...(for...)

raw_glosses: (with sē) to be pleased (with oneself), to be content
glosses: to be pleased (with oneself), to be content

raw_glosses: (with infinitive) to be accustomed (to), enjoy an activity
glosses: to be accustomed (to), enjoy an activity

examples.text: Ō Thāis mea, meum sāvium, quid agitur? Ecquid nōs amās dē fīdīcinā istāc?
examples.ref: c. 185 BCE – 159 BCE, Publius Terentius Afer, The Eunuch
examples.english: O Thais, my sweetie, what's happening? Are you grateful to us for that harpist?

examples.text: Bene facis, meritō tē amō.
examples.ref: ~160 BCE, Publius Terentius Afer, The Brothers
examples.english: You're very kind, I'm rightly obliged to you.

examples.text: Dē raudusculō Numeriānō multum tē amō.
examples.ref: 68 BCE – 44 BCE, Cicero, Epistulae ad Atticum CXXIII, (The phrase raudusculo Numeriano, "Numerius' bit of coin", here refers to a small monetary debt assumedly having been owed by Cicero to Numerius, and paid for Cicero by Atticus)
examples.english: Regarding Numerius' bit of coin I am very much obliged to you.

glosses: to be thankful, grateful to, feel obliged for a service

etymology_text:
From Proto-Italic *pōtlom, from Proto-Indo-European *péh₃tlom, derived from the root *peh₃- (“to drink”) (whence also bibō).
Cognate with Old Irish ól, and Sanskrit पात्र (pātra).

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin first and second declension adjectives
Latin first and second declension adjectives with nominative masculine singular in -er
etymology_text:
Uncertain. The earlier form polcer is traditionally derived from Proto-Italic *porkros, from Proto-Indo-European *pr̥ḱ-ró-s or Proto-Indo-European *perḱ-ro-, from the root *perḱ- (“motley, variegated”), with dissimilation of the first *-r- into *-l-, though this has been challenged. Connection with poliō (“to polish, smooth”) or polleō (“to be strong”) is to be excluded.
The aspiration is often considered secondary when the word would have been made to derive from Ancient Greek πολύχροος (polúkhroos, “multicolor”) by folk etymology, while an Etruscan borrowing is usually discarded.

args.1: For this compare triumphus, Carthāgō, and also English anthem, author, Anthony, etc.

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
etymology_text:
From a compound involving co- (“with”) and ōs, ōris (“mouth”). Perhaps from an intermediate Proto-Italic adjective *co-os-o-(s), with ending taken from clam. Compare palam.
The ablative is from the PIE comitative-instrumental.

examples.english: Thou shalt have no other gods before me.

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin terms derived from the Proto-Indo-European root *h₃reǵ-
etymology_text:
Equivalent to an adverbial derivation from *ēregō, presumably ex- + regō, with sense similar to cognate pergō (“I proceed”).
See also ergā. Compare with the adverbial use of ē regiōne (“directly, against”), with the same elements.

examples.ref: Late 4th century, Jerome [et al.], transl., edited by Roger Gryson, Biblia Sacra: Iuxta Vulgatam Versionem (Vulgate), 5th edition, Stuttgart: Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft, published 2007, →ISBN, 1:1:

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
etymology_text: Seems connected with ob and ad, thus its strict meaning would be “on to”, “unto”.

examples.text: qua de causa/qua de re/quam ob causam
examples.translation: for this reason/therefore
examples.english: for this reason/therefore

examples.text:
Ille diēs prīmus lētī prīmusque malōrum
causa fuit ….
That day – a first of death, and onset of misery – it was the cause [of everything].
examples.ref: 29 BCE – 19 BCE, Virgil, Aeneid 4.169–170
examples.english: (The union of Dido and Aeneas begets tragedy.)
examples.translation: (The union of Dido and Aeneas begets tragedy.)

examples.text: SĪMŌ: Nē haec quidem / satis vehemēns causa ad objūrgandum.
examples.ref: 166 BCE, Publius Terentius Afer, Andria 149–150
examples.english: SIMO: Even this was not a strong enough reason to reprimand [my son].
examples.translation: SIMO: Even this was not a strong enough reason to reprimand [my son].

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin feminine nouns in the first declension
Latin terms derived from Old Latin
etymology_text: From Old Latin caussa, from Proto-Italic *kaussā, further origin unknown. Connected by some to Latin cudo (“I strike”), in the sense "strike a cause," in which the Proto-Indo-European form would be *kewh₂-ud-ʰ-t-, from *kewh₂- (“to cut, strike”). Others are skeptical of an Indo-European origin. Related to Etruscan 𐌂𐌀𐌅𐌔𐌀 (cavsa).

examples.text: urbis causā
examples.translation: for the sake of the city
examples.english: for the sake of the city

glosses: for the sake of, on account of

Others are skeptical of an Indo-European origin. Related to Etruscan 𐌂𐌀𐌅𐌔𐌀 (cavsa).

etymology_text: From et (“even”) + sī (“if”).

examples.text: Quid fēcī?
examples.translation: What have I done?
examples.english: What have I done?

raw_tags: special usage; passive perfect = took place, lit. has been made/is done
examples.text: Latrōcinium modo factum est.
examples.translation: A robbery just took place.
examples.english: A robbery just took place.

examples.text: Factum est.
examples.translation: (It) is done.
examples.english: (It) is done.

examples.text: Quam diu quisquam erit qui te defendere audeat, vives, et vives ita ut nunc vivis, multis meis et firmis praesidiis obsessus ne commovere te contra rem publicam possis. Multorum te etiam oculi et aures non sentientem, sicut adhuc fecerunt, speculabuntur atque custodient.
examples.ref: 63 BCE, Cicero, Catiline Orations:
examples.english: As long as one person exists who can dare to defend you, you shall live; but you shall live as you do now, surrounded by my many and trusty guards, so that you shall not be able to stir one finger against the republic: many eyes and ears shall still observe and watch you, as they have hitherto done, though you shall not perceive them.
examples.translation: As long as one person exists who can dare to defend you, you shall live; but you shall live as you do now, surrounded by my many and trusty guards, so that you shall not be able to stir one finger against the republic: many eyes and ears shall still observe and watch you, as they have hitherto done, though you shall not perceive them.

glosses: to do (particularly as a specific instance or occasion of doing)
to make, construct, fashion, frame, build, erect

examples.english: And God said: Let light be made. And light was made.
examples.translation: And God said: Let light be made. And light was made.

etymology_text:
Etymology tree
Proto-Italic *fakjō
Latin faciō
Inherited from Proto-Italic *fakjō, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰh₁k-yé-ti (“to put; place”). Doublet of -ficō.
The passive voice is suppletively provided by the etymologically unrelated fīō.

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin terms derived from Old Latin
Latin terms derived from the Proto-Indo-European root *h₂el- (other)
Latin terms inherited from Old Latin
Pages linking to anchors not found in Appendix:Glossary
etymology_text:
From Old Latin olle (“he, that”) (also ollus, olla), from Proto-Italic *olnos, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂ol-no-s or *h₂l̥-no-s, from *h₂el- (“beyond, other”). Cognate with Latin ūls (“beyond”), alius (“other”), and alter (“the other”); Umbrian ulu (“to that place”), Old Church Slavonic лани (lani, “last year”, literally “in that (year)”).
Initial i- from o- has no parallel case and may be owing to contamination from is, iste and/or due to the palatalizing effect of l exilis.

etymology_templates.name: cog
etymology_templates.expansion: Old Church Slavonic лани (lani, “last year”, literally “in that (year)”)

glosses: that one; that (thing); those ones (in the plural); those (things); he, she, it

examples.text: Mūsae, quae pedibus magnum pulsātis Olympum
examples.ref: 239 BCE – 169 BCE, Ennius, Annales 1, (fragment in Varro, De Lingua Latina 7.20)
examples.english: O Muses, who with your feet press great Olympus...
examples.translation: O Muses, who with your feet press great Olympus...

examples.text:
Nam quod ā Graecīs nunc κλέπτης dīcitur, antīquiōre Graecā linguā φὼρ dictum est. Hinc per adfīnitātem litterārum, quī φὼρ Graecē, est Latīnē 'fūr'.
For, what is now said a κλέπτης by the Greeks, in older Greek language φώρ was said. Hence, by affinity of the letters, he who [is] a φώρ in Greek is in Latin a fūr.
examples.ref: c. 177 CE, Aulus Gellius, Noctes Atticae 1.18.5

examples.text: Quoniam fīliī sānctōrum sumus, et vītam illam expectāmus, quam Deus datūrus est hīs quī fidem suam numquam mūtant ab eō.
examples.ref: 405 CE, Jerome, Vulgate Tobit.2.18
examples.english: For we are the children of saints, and look for that life which God will give to those that never change their faith from him.
examples.translation: For we are the children of saints, and look for that life which God will give to those that never change their faith from him.

examples.text: Mors hominum felix, quae se nec dulcibus annis
examples.ref: c. 524 CE, Boethius, De philosophiae consolatione 1.1
examples.english: Fortunate is that human death that doesn't step in during one's sweet years, and comes to the sorrowful after being often called!
examples.translation: Fortunate is that human death that doesn't step in during one's sweet years, and comes to the sorrowful after being often called!
examples.roman: Inserit et maestis saepe uocata uenit.

examples.text: Qui enim cantus moderata oratione dulcior inveniri potest? Quod carmen artificiosa verborum conclusione aptius? Qui actor imitanda quam orator suscipienda veritate iucundior?
examples.ref: 55 BCE, Cicero, De Oratore 2.34
examples.english: What music can be found more sweet than the pronunciation of a well-ordered oration? What poem more agreeable than the skilful structure of prose? What actor has ever given greater pleasure in imitating, than an orator gives in supporting, truth?
examples.translation: What music can be found more sweet than the pronunciation of a well-ordered oration? What poem more agreeable than the skilful structure of prose? What actor has ever given greater pleasure in imitating, than an orator gives in supporting, truth?

examples.text: Sī quae peregrīna nāvis in portum advenit, rogitant cuiātis sit
examples.ref: c. 200 BCE, Plautus, Menaechmi 340
examples.english: If any foreign ship comes into the port, they ask where it comes from
examples.translation: If any foreign ship comes into the port, they ask where it comes from

examples.text: Ariovistum … obsidēs nōbilissimī cuiusque līberōs poscere, et in eōs omnia exempla cruciatūsque ēdere, sī qua rēs nōn ad nūtum aut ad voluntātem eius facta sit.
examples.ref: c. 52 BCE, Julius Caesar, Commentarii de Bello Gallico 1.31
examples.english: Ariovistus ... demanded the children of all the high nobles as hostages, and afflict them with every kind of cruelty, if anything wasn't done with his approval or for his pleasure.
examples.translation: Ariovistus ... demanded the children of all the high nobles as hostages, and afflict them with every kind of cruelty, if anything wasn't done with his approval or for his pleasure.

examples.text: ne quem post se hostem relinqueret
examples.ref: c. 52 BCE, Julius Caesar, Commentarii de Bello Gallico 7.11
examples.english: lest he should leave any enemy behind him
examples.translation: lest he should leave any enemy behind him

examples.text: Ut si qua ex parte
examples.ref: c. 52 BCE, Julius Caesar, Commentarii de Bello Gallico 7.28
examples.english: That if from any side
examples.translation: That if from any side

examples.text: […] dum ne quem militem legeret ex eo numero quibus senatus missionem reditumque in patriam negasset ante belli finem.
examples.ref: 27 BCE – 25 BCE, Titus Livius, Ab Urbe Condita 26.1
examples.english: […] provided he did not choose any soldier from those to whom the Senate had refused discharge and a return home before the end of the war
examples.translation: […] provided he did not choose any soldier from those to whom the Senate had refused discharge and a return home before the end of the war

raw_glosses: (indefinite, after si, nisi, num, ne) anyone, any

head_templates.name: la-det
head_templates.expansion: quī or quis (feminine quae or qua, neuter quod); relative/interrogative determiner

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
Latin terms derived from the Proto-Indo-European root *kʷ-

related.word: † Turned conjunction with original meaning somewhat dissimilated° Rare‡only used as a conjunction
not as an interrogative* Ridiculed by most grammarians

etymology_text:
Etymology tree
Proto-Indo-European *kʷ-
Proto-Indo-European *kʷos
Proto-Italic *kʷoi
Latin quei
Latin qui
From earlier quei, from Proto-Italic *kʷoi, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷís, *kʷos.

raw_glosses: (interrogative) In what way? how? whereby? by what means? why?
glosses: In what way? how? whereby? by what means? why?

examples.text: Ea quī cōnficeret, C. Trebōnium lēgātum relinquit.
examples.ref: c. 52 BCE, Julius Caesar, Commentarii de Bello Gallico VII.11
examples.english: To complete these arrangements, he leaves C. Trebonius in command.
examples.translation: To complete these arrangements, he leaves C. Trebonius in command.

raw_glosses: (relative) wherewith, whereby, wherefrom, how; that, in order that
glosses: wherewith, whereby, wherefrom, how; that, in order that

raw_glosses: (indefinite, with hercle, edepol, at, quippe, ut) somehow, surely

categories: Latin entries with incorrect language header
etymology_text: Old instrumental case of quis, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷíh₁ (“how?”). Cognate with English why.
